title: The Suffering and Praise of the Messiah
shortSummary: Psalm 22 is a prophetic psalm of David expressing deep anguish and abandonment, yet culminating in confident praise and hope. It vividly portrays the suffering of the Messiah, His trust in God despite intense distress, and the ultimate victory and worship of God by all nations.
timeline: c. 1000 BC - Reign of King David

keyCharacters.name: David
keyCharacters.description: The author of this psalm, expressing personal anguish that prophetically points to the Messiah's suffering.

keyCharacters.name: The Messiah
keyCharacters.description: The anointed one whose suffering and eventual triumph are foreshadowed throughout the psalm.

keyCharacters.name: The Wicked
keyCharacters.description: Those who mock, surround, and pierce the psalmist, representing enemies and persecutors.

definitions.definition: A musical term or tune to which this psalm was to be sung, possibly meaning 'hind of the dawn.'
Strong and powerful bulls from the fertile region of Bashan, symbolizing fierce enemies.
Likely referring to a strong wild ox or rhinoceros, symbolizing strength and power in ancient texts.
A broken piece of pottery, used metaphorically here to describe weakness and dryness.

outline.heading: Cry of Abandonment and Despair
outline.description: The psalmist begins with a heartfelt cry of feeling forsaken by God, yet recalls God's holiness and faithfulness to Israel's ancestors, establishing a tension between present suffering and past deliverance.

outline.heading: Description of Intense Suffering
outline.description: Vivid imagery describes physical and emotional agony, rejection by people, and enemies surrounding and piercing the psalmist, foreshadowing the Messiah’s crucifixion.

outline.heading: Plea for Deliverance
outline.description: The psalmist urgently calls on God for rescue from death and enemies, expressing trust that God hears and will save.

outline.heading: Declaration of Praise and Proclamation
outline.description: The tone shifts to confident praise and public declaration of God's name, promising that all nations will worship the Lord and future generations will proclaim His righteousness.

application: In times of deep distress, believers can cry out honestly to God, trusting He hears and will ultimately deliver.
Christians should remember God's faithfulness to past generations as encouragement to trust Him in present trials.
We are called to publicly proclaim God's name and righteousness, even after experiencing hardship.
Recognize that suffering can have redemptive purpose and leads to greater worship and dependence on God.

keyVerses.text: My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me? why art thou so far from helping me, and from the words of my roaring?
keyVerses.significance: This opening verse expresses the profound feeling of abandonment that the Messiah experienced, quoted by Jesus on the cross.

keyVerses.text: For dogs have compassed me: the assembly of the wicked have inclosed me: they pierced my hands and my feet.
keyVerses.significance: This verse prophetically describes the crucifixion wounds of the Messiah, affirming the psalm’s Messianic nature.

keyVerses.text: I will declare thy name unto my brethren: in the midst of the congregation will I praise thee.
keyVerses.significance: This verse marks the turning point from suffering to praise, emphasizing public worship and testimony to God's faithfulness.

keyVerses.text: All the ends of the world shall remember and turn unto the LORD: and all the kindreds of the nations shall worship before thee.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the universal scope of God's kingdom and the ultimate worship of all nations.
